unit_learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the inter-professional nature of health care, the need for various investigations in the diagnosis of pathological conditions and the role of referral.
Formulate differential diagnoses, based on history and examination findings.
Describe the principles and purpose of the diagnostic process.
Explain the relationship between the clinical presentation of a patient, the underlying disease processes, and the diagnostic process.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Preparation of set questions for each weekly tutorial. 2 hours per week for 12 weeks.
Weekly readings following on from the lectures and in preparation for the tutorials. Approximately 2hr20min per week for 12 weeks.

assessments.description: This will cover the content of the entire semester. Questions will include Multiple choice questions and Short answer questions.
The mid-session exam will consist of short-answer questions and will cover material up to the mid-session break.
5 online multiple-choice quizzes spread throughout the session. Each quiz is worth 4%.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances
data.description: In this unit, students are introduced to the concept of clinical problem solving and differential diagnosis. It aims to provide students with the knowledge and skills to assess the health status of a patient. Using this information, possible problems that may exist for that patient can then be outlined. This unit focuses on diagnosis from a 'symptom' and 'sign' based approach, where students will analyse the information given, and hence formulate a differential diagnosis.
data.title: Diagnostic Sciences

title: Diagnostic Sciences
